newsitem.title: FRANCE: Suspected car bomb hits central Algiers.
newsitem.headline: Suspected car bomb hits central Algiers.

text.p: A large explosion, believed to be a car bomb, rocked central Algiers on Tuesday afternoon, residents said.

Speaking by telephone from Algiers, they described a huge explosion in the area of the main university faculty at one end of the main shopping street, Rue Didouche Mourad. One quoted a taxi driver who said he had witnessed the blast which was believed to have been a car bomb.
There was no immediate information on casualties or comment from the authorities.
Algiers has been the target of numerous bomb attacks blamed by the authorities on Moslem fundamentalists. Two car bombs in Algiers late in December killed at least 18 people.
The latest blast occurred amid a spate of rebel raids on villages in which at least 38 people were killed within a 24-hour period last week.
The violence flared as Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyahia said in a speech his government had crushed the Islamist guerrillas.

About 60,000 people have been killed, including more than 1,400 in bomb attacks, in Algeria since early 1992 when the authorities cancelled a general election in which radical Islamists had taken a commanding lead.

The worst bombing in Algiers was in 1995 when Moslem rebels slammed a car laden with explosives into the main police station in Colonel Amirouche street, killing more than 40 people and wounding more than 300.
